div.p:
We shall rejoice if you accept of Sir P. Peter Burel's offer offer as it will give us a chance of seeing you & yours at this place. Gwedir Gwydir Castle in the Conwy valley. Peter Burrell's title from 1796 links him with Gwydir. is a in a most pleasant country with good roads about, has a market near & is I believe well enough furnished for so transient a
time as you propose to use it.

Moses has done all the arms in the Snowdon part of my wales , & seven or eight larger views in Chester He will do the arms of in of the first volume
in the manner you direct. Pray inform me would you have the Snowdon par
sent to you when it is done: but I am fearful that it will not be executed under a month to come.

The influenza has seized my family. Mrs Pennant is recovered, but several of our servants are ill. If they recover in time we leave home for a fortnight on the 29th. we are to visit a friend near worcester:This is Treadway Russell Nash, who lived at Bevere near Worcester from 1758 and whom Pennant visited again during 1791 and 1797 according to the evidence of these letters. LINK TO BIOGRAPHIES: Treadway Russell Nash
from where I shall Elope or hone at Berkley Castle Berkeley Castle in Gloucestershire was at this time owned by Frederick Augustus Berkeley, fifth Earl of Berkeley (1745â€“1810). to complete an iter sabrinum.In Literary life, p. 28, Pennant writes of a journey by boat down the Severn from Atcham-bridge, south of Shrewsbury, as far as the home of Treadway Russell Nash in Bevere, Worcestershire, dating it to June 1783. For an earlier reference to the 'iter sabrinum', see NLW 15423C, T[readway Russell] Nash to Thomas Pennant, 13 July 1777. an attempt long since begun & in great part finished. The seeing the light is another affair. If you do not visit Wales, pray write to inform me where you fix.

closer.salute:
With best wishes for every individual of yr
your house I am
Dear Sir
Most truely yrs
yours
closer.dateline: Downing June 21 1782.The year, 1782, is on a new line. Could this possibly be an addition by Bull, and erroneous in view of the evidence of Pennant's Literary life, which describes a journey down the Severn in June 1783, in the company of Nash, his wife and daughter, together with David Pennant, again using 'elopement' as a term to describe it. That journey went no further than Beverley (Bevere), however.
